<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_linux_probe_driver:
```c
static int metal_linux_probe_driver(struct linux_bus *lbus,
				    struct linux_driver *ldrv)
{
	char command[256];
	int ret;

	ldrv->sdrv = sysfs_open_driver(lbus->bus_name, ldrv->drv_name);

	/* Try probing the module and then open the driver. */
	if (!ldrv->sdrv) {
		ret = snprintf(command, sizeof(command),
			       "modprobe %s > /dev/null 2>&1", ldrv->mod_name);
		if (ret >= (int)sizeof(command))
			return -EOVERFLOW;
		ret = system(command);
		if (ret < 0) {
			metal_log(METAL_LOG_WARNING,
				  "%s: executing system command '%s' failed.\n",
				  __func__, command);
		}
		ldrv->sdrv = sysfs_open_driver(lbus->bus_name, ldrv->drv_name);
	}

	/* Try sudo probing the module and then open the driver. */
	if (!ldrv->sdrv) {
		ret = snprintf(command, sizeof(command),
			       "sudo modprobe %s > /dev/null 2>&1", ldrv->mod_name);
		if (ret >= (int)sizeof(command))
			return -EOVERFLOW;
		ret = system(command);
		if (ret < 0) {
			metal_log(METAL_LOG_WARNING,
				  "%s: executing system command '%s' failed.\n",
				  __func__, command);
		}
		ldrv->sdrv = sysfs_open_driver(lbus->bus_name, ldrv->drv_name);
	}

	/* If all else fails... */
	return ldrv->sdrv ? 0 : -ENODEV;
}
```

static int metal_linux_probe_bus(struct linux_bus *lbus)
{
	struct linux_driver *ldrv;
	int ret, error = -ENODEV;

	lbus->sbus = sysfs_open_bus(lbus->bus_name);
	if (!lbus->sbus)
		return -ENODEV;

	for_each_linux_driver(lbus, ldrv) {
		ret = metal_linux_probe_driver(lbus, ldrv);
		/* Clear the error if any driver is available */
		if (!ret)
			error = ret;
	}

	if (error) {
		metal_linux_bus_close(&lbus->bus);
		return error;
	}

	error = metal_linux_register_bus(lbus);
	if (error)
		metal_linux_bus_close(&lbus->bus);

	return error;
}
...
static void metal_linux_bus_close(struct metal_bus *bus)
{
	struct linux_bus *lbus = to_linux_bus(bus);
	struct linux_driver *ldrv;

	for_each_linux_driver(lbus, ldrv) {
		if (ldrv->sdrv)
			sysfs_close_driver(ldrv->sdrv);
		ldrv->sdrv = NULL;
	}

	sysfs_close_bus(lbus->sbus);
	lbus->sbus = NULL;
}
...
static int metal_linux_register_bus(struct linux_bus *lbus)
{
	lbus->bus.name = lbus->bus_name;
	lbus->bus.ops  = metal_linux_bus_ops;
	return metal_bus_register(&lbus->bus);
}
...
int metal_linux_bus_init(void)
{
	struct linux_bus *lbus;
	int valid = 0;

	for_each_linux_bus(lbus)
		valid += metal_linux_probe_bus(lbus) ? 0 : 1;

	return valid ? 0 : -ENODEV;
}

explanation: The listed fragments were selected because they involve calls that may trigger external actions or callbacks and therefore could potentially lead to indirect re-entry of the probe routine (they should be examined for possible indirect recursion paths). Other parts of the code do not need investigation for Rule 17.2 because they are simple non-calling constructs or do not invoke functions that could reasonably call back into the probe functions: for example, the snprintf usages are pure formatting calls and cannot call back; the checks of return values and simple assignments/returns contain no function calls that could cause recursion; structure and typedef declarations and the driver function-pointer member declarations are definitions only (the function-pointer members are not invoked inside metal_linux_probe_driver); sysfs_close_bus and the simple cleanup code in metal_linux_bus_close are straightforward closing operations and do not call metal_linux_probe_driver; metal_linux_register_bus only registers the bus and does not call the probe function. These non-listed fragments therefore do not appear to present a risk of direct or indirect self-calls under Rule 17.2.
